clues.text: Nickname of Eddie Felson, a pool hustler of novels & films
Edgar Rice Burroughs created "John Carter Of" this nearby planet
Alden Pyle, Graham Greene's "Quiet American", is a CIA agent in this Asian country when the French still run it
Pulp writer Max Brand created this doctor played on TV by Richard Chamberlain
We get misty thinking of this Jules Verne Englishman who goes "Around The World In 80 Days"
In 1957 Lake Seminole was created on the Apalachicola River in this state but most of it lies in Georgia
The U.S. Bureau of the Census says its metropolitan area covers parts of 3 states:  Wisconsin, Illinois & Indiana
The Humboldt River, this state's longest, flows through the cities of Winnemucca & Elko
The name of this iron ore-producing range in Minnesota comes from an Indian word for "giant"
This presidential mountain in New Hampshire is the tallest peak in the northeastern United States
In 1892 the Illinois legislature made this president's birthday a legal holiday
Canada honors its soldiers on Remembrance Day, the same date as this U.S. holiday
Girls in this country display valuable dolls that are family heirlooms on Hina Matsuri
In July Tahitians celebrate Tiurai, centered around this French holiday, with dance contests & other activities
Guy Fawkes Day commemorates the Gunpowder Plot in which Guy Fawkes tried to blow up this king & his parliament
Chief Blackfish adopted this Kentucky explorer, guide & later state legislator
Cameahwait had planned on attacking this pair's expedition, until he noticed their guide was his sister
Of Meadowlark, Geese or Curly, the Crow who served as a scout for Custer at Little Big Horn
He was an ally of the British in the War of 1812 & a Wisconsin city is named for him, b'gosh
Hiawatha was the founder of this Native American league
Charlton Heston in "The Agony and the Ecstasy"
Jose Ferrer in "Moulin Rouge"
Anthony Quinn in "Lust for Life"
David Bowie in "Basquiat"

Tremble, or a place to keep your arrows
In math, divide one number by another & you'll get this
Because it's liquid & flows rapidly, Mercury is also known by this name
Located just south of the Equator, it's South America's oldest capital
This term for a traitor comes from the name of a Norwegian traitor of WWII

rounds.comments: (Alex: You're all too young to remember!)

clues.text: In 1951 this Oklahoman replaced Joe DiMaggio as the Yankees' starting center fielder
Nickname given to Eisenhower's theory that if one Asian country falls to Communism, others will follow
He's credited with coining the term "beat" to describe a generation

He spent the entire decade as chancellor of West Germany
South Korea's Se Ri Pak, a star in this sport, is sometimes called "Tigress Woods"
French high-wire artist Philippe Petit is known for his 1974 walk between the towers of this NYC landmark
B.K.S. Iyengar of India is often called the world's foremost teacher of this body-twisting practice
Albums like "Romanza" & "Aria" have made this blind Italian tenor a superstar
In 1997 he was knighted for writing plays; in 1999 he was Oscared for "Shakespeare In Love"
This Indiana town shares its name with a popular theater snack reportedly given to the Pilgrims by the Indians
This Ohio town shares its name with Hosea's Old Testament wife & the first name of a TV military hayseed
This Oregon town could be the theoretical home of a doll, 1983's most popular Christmas toy
It's the only town in Illinois bearing the name of a mid-'70s dance craze
George Michael didn't found this Louisiana town, but it does bear the name of his old pop duo
Our sun is classified as the yellow type of these "small" stars
Like those of the genus Malus, most wild apples are of this tart "crustacean" type
Of 6,000, 66,000 or 666,000 MPH, the closest to the speed of the Earth around the sun
2 of the 4 stages of development for most insects
The adult human brain is made up of more than 10 billion of these nerve cells
This rock pioneer's first & only No. 1 hit was 1957's "That'll Be The Day"
The Beatles had 20 No. 1 singles; this man had 18
Her rendition of "The Star-Spangled Banner" at the 1991 Super Bowl took the song into the Top 40 for the first time
On the U.S. Billboard Top 40 chart, this UB40 hit climbed to No. 34 in 1984 & to No. 1 in 1988

rounds.text: Before Michael Phelps in 2008, he was the last American to win 5 individual golds in one Olympics; he did it at Lake Placid
